awd_titl_txt: CCF-BSF: CIF: Small: Coding Techniques for Emerging Storage Technologies.
awd_abstract_narration:
Magnetic media and flash memories are currently the main platforms used for mass data storage. As the need for storage capacity grows, new methods are being explored to increase the density in such media, and new nano-scale technologies, such as memristor-based memories, are being developed. This project concerns the analysis of fundamental limits on the information storage capability of these emerging storage technologies, as well as the design of coding schemes to approach those limits. The theoretical component of the project requires new approaches in information theory and discrete mathematics, while the development of new coding techniques extends the reach of the theory into practice, hastening the evolution of new commercial technologies.  The project provides a stimulating research environment for graduate students, and contributes to curriculum development in electrical engineering and computer science. 

In the domain of magnetic storage, the research addresses lower and upper bounds on the capacity of grain and Ising channels; the construction of codes that correct errors in these channels; and the extension of these results to non-binary channel models. The research on multilevel flash memories involves computing bounds on the capacity of the one-dimensional inter-cell interference channel; constructing codes that combat inter-cell interference in one, two, and three dimensions; and designing codes that mitigate the wear of cells and the erase-program asymmetry in flash memories. For memristor-based memories, research topics include the design of two-dimensional codes with weight constraints on the rows and columns; the design of fast methods for overwriting a two-dimensional weight-constrained array onto another constrained array; and the study of the notion of Hamming connectedness of constraints.

por.por_cntn:
Magnetic media, optical media, and flash memories are currently the main platforms used for mass data storage. As the need for storage capacity exponentially grows, new methods are urgently needed to increase the density in such media, while the development of new nano-scale technologies, such as memristor-array memories and DNA-based storage, needs to be expedited.

This project concerned the analysis of fundamental limits on the information storage capability of these different storage technologies, as well as the design of coding schemes to approach those limits. The theoretical component of the project required new approaches in information theory and discrete mathematics, while the development of new coding techniques extended the reach of the theory into practice, hastening the evolution of new commercial technologies through collaboration with industrial research laboratories.  The project provided a stimulating research environment for resident and visiting graduate students and created opportunities for relevant summer internships in the storage industry. As part of the NSF cooperative research program with the US-Israel Binational Science Foundation (BSF), this project included substantial collaborative research with professors from Technion ? Israel Institute of Technology.

The intellectual merit of the research derived from the advancement of our information-theoretic understanding of the potential and limitations of modern storage technologies, as well as the development and implementation of algorithms for efficient and reliable storage of information in devices and systems based upon these technologies. The broader impacts of the research stem from the influence of our results upon the development of improved data storage technology through experimental validation of theory and algorithms, transfer of results to the storage industry, and the training of skilled graduate students who contribute to advanced  technology development through their research, summer internships, and eventual employment in academia and the  storage industry.

Our main theoretical findings include a proof of the equivalence of several concepts of the information-theoretic capacity for two-dimensional channels with intersymbol interference which are used to model high-density magnetic, optical, and solid-state memories. We also analyzed a broadcast channel model for multilevel flash memory that sheds light on the potential for increasing the memory capacity by using joint encoding of pages, rather than the current practice of separate encoding, while retaining independent decoding of the pages. Our information-theoretic analysis of intercell-interference (ICI) in flash memory yielded insight into its effects upon capacity, as well as properties of coded signals that can achieve the capacity when the ICI is not too severe. For certain classes of constrained codes that are used to combat ICI in multilevel flash memory and that also provide a prescribed ratio of different programmed cell levels, as driven by other system requirements, we developed a closed-form analytical expression to determine the maximum achievable information rate. Using a costly-channel model for flash memory wear, we characterized the trade-off between rate and average wear for wear-reducing  shaping codes, identifying an optimal code rate, and showing the equivalence of shaping codes to codes that optimally match a specified code symbol distribution. Finally, we developed an upper bound on the capacity of a channel model that captures many of the attributes of DNA-based data storage technology.

Our advances in algorithms for coding include techniques for designing two-dimensional constrained codes to mitigate ICI in flash memory that are amenable to practical row-by-row encoding. We showed how to use these techniques to design one-dimensional weakly constrained codes that achieve a prescribed frequency of occurrence of specified code patterns as required in some applications.  We also found necessary and sufficient conditions for the existence of parity-preserving constrained codes, exemplified by the Blu-Ray Disc code, as well as practical construction methods.  We developed a general method for constructing optimal shaping codes for wear mitigation, combining lossless data compression and the class of Varn codes.  In the area of error-correction codes (ECCs), we created the class of syndrome-coupled rate-compatible codes that enable the use of many existing classes of ECCs in settings where code rate adaptation is required to handle degraded channel conditions.  We also developed several ECC techniques for distributed storage arrays, including partial MDS codes, multi-erasure locally recoverable codes, and ladder codes with shared redundancy. Finally, we proposed new ECC constructions and bounds for codes over sets intended for use in DNA storage applications.

Our experimental studies made use of an extensive database of hard and soft error measurements on multilevel flash memory that we collected in our lab.  These unique error datasets were used to verify the significant performance improvements  provided by our shaping codes and rate-compatible ECCs  based upon BCH and LDPC codes.  The LDPC-based codes were evaluated using both hard-decision decoding and superior, but more complex, soft-decision decoding. The error datasets were also used to show the effectiveness of novel machine learning approaches to prediction of page-read failures in flash memory.
